Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Situation2: They are listed as the sole speaker for this week's congregational sermon, and the community has publicized their topic.
Story: I stared at my phone, thumb hovering over the screen. My mother’s message blinked at me: “Are you coming home this weekend?” I hadn’t replied to her last text, and guilt pricked at me. She always said, “Just let us know you’re okay.” I knew how much it meant to her, especially since I moved out. But my mind was already tangled with the sermon I had to deliver tomorrow. The community had been waiting for this topic—my name was on the flyers, and people had told me how much they were looking forward to it. I was the only imam scheduled, and there was no one to cover for me. I felt the weight of their expectations, the responsibility to guide and inspire. Yet, my parents’ quiet hope for a call or a visit pressed on me just as hard. I wanted to be a good daughter, to reassure them, but I also couldn’t let my congregation down. My heart twisted as I sat between the two worlds, phone in hand, unable to move.
